contextId.information: This is an idiom that means to be possessed by an unclean spirit. AT: "is possessed by an unclean spirit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the phrase "has come" is an idiom for the grain being ripe for harvest. AT: "because the grain is ready to be harvested" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "arose" is an idiom for "began." AT: "a violent windstorm began" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom meaning that the man is "controlled" or "possessed" by the unclean spirit. AT: "controlled by an unclean spirit" or "that an unclean spirit possessed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom meaning that he is thinking clearly. AT: "of a normal mind" or "thinking clearly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means it was late in the day. AT: "When it was getting late" or "Late in the afternoon" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means the boy is possessed by an unclean spirit. "He has an unclean spirit" or "He is possessed by an unclean spirit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that Jesus grasped the boy's hand with his own hand. AT: "grasped the boy by the hand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to do something because of love for Jesus. AT: "because they love me" (UDB) or "for my sake" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that he is not among their group of disciples. AT: "he is not one of us" or "he does not walk with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that they were very stubborn. AT: "your stubbornness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that they allowed them to continue doing what they were doing. AT: "let them take the donkey with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that there is only one God. AT: "there is only one God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This idiom means that something is more important than something else. In this case, these two commandments are more pleasing to God that burnt offering and sacrifices. This may be written clearly. AT: "is even more important than" or "is even more pleasing to God than" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to arrest someone and then put them under someone else's control. AT: "arrest you and give you over to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to be put on trial and judged. AT: "You will be put on trial before" or "You will be brought to trial and judged by" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to put them under someone else's control. In this case, under the authorities' control. AT: "give you over to the authorities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means that he is very near and has almost arrived, referring to a traveler being close to arriving at the city gates. AT: "and is almost here" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means leave. AT: "will leave me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This means that God will raise Jesus from the dead. This can be written in active form. AT: "God raises me from the  dead" or "God makes me alive again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
If in your language you have to name the person who curses someone, state God. AT: "to say for God to curse him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This idiom means that he was overwhelmed with grief and lost control of his emotions. AT: "he was overwhelmed with grief" or "he lost control of his emotions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Jesus is rebuking his disciples because they would not believe in him. Translate this idiom so it is understood that the disciples were not believing Jesus. AT: "refusal to believe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"showed that his words, which they were speaking, were true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
